questions.text: A 40-year-old female consumed a white colored rodenticide powder and presents with a potassium level of 2.5 mEq/L. She has irregular pulse and muscle paralysis. ECG shows multiple ventricular ectopic beats. What is the suspected poison? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium Carbonate

 

Barium carbonate poisoning is characterized by severe hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which leads to symptoms such as muscle paralysis and irregular pulse. The ECG changes, such as multiple ventricular ectopic beats, are also indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aluminum Phosphide: This poison releases phosphine gas in the stomach, which inhibits cytochrome C oxidase and causes oxidative stress, leading to cytotoxic effects. The main symptom is profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option B. Zinc Phosphide: Similar to aluminum phosphide, zinc phosphide also releases phosphine gas and causes oxidative stress and cytochrome C oxidase inhibition, leading to cytotoxic effects and profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Warfarin: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that causes bleeding and bruising with an elevated PT/INR, but it does not cause hypokalemia or the associated symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia with symptoms such as muscle paralysis, irregular pulse, and ECG changes like ventricular ectopic beats strongly suggest poisoning with barium carbonate.

questions.text: Blood supply for the red shaded area in the given image is a branch of which artery? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

 

 

 

The red shaded area in the given image indicates a portion of the lateral medulla. The blood supply to this area is provided by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery. This area is typically involved in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

 

  • Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA): This artery is a branch of the vertebral artery and supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. Damage to this artery can lead to lateral medullary syndrome, characterized by various neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior cerebellar artery: This artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and does not supply the lateral medulla.

 

Option B. Posterior cerebral artery: This artery primarily supplies the occipital lobe and parts of the temporal lobe, not the lateral medulla.

 

Option D. Basilar artery: While the basilar artery gives rise to the superior cerebellar artery and the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, it does not directly supply the lateral medulla. The vertebral arteries, which form the basilar artery, give rise to PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

choices.text: Abdominal sling surgery

questions.text: A 24-year-old nulligravida presents with uterine prolapse. There is no cystocele or rectocele. What is the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abdominal sling surgery

 

The correct answer is abdominal sling surgery. In a young nulligravida (a woman who has never been pregnant), the preferred treatment for uterine prolapse without cystocele or rectocele is usually a type of sling surgery, also known as hysteropexy. This procedure involves suspending the uterus to a supportive structure within the pelvis, preserving the uterus and maintaining the possibility of future pregnancies.

 

Abdominal sling surgery (Hysteropexy): This procedure is indicated for young women, particularly those who have not completed their family or desire future fertility. It involves attaching the uterus to a ligament or other supportive structure in the pelvis to provide the necessary support and correct the prolapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leforte colpocleisis: This is a procedure typically reserved for very old women who are no longer sexually active and not fit for major surgery. It involves closing off the vaginal canal, which is not suitable for a young nulligravida.

 

Option B. Fothergill surgery (Manchester operation): This procedure involves cervical amputation and plication of the cardinal ligaments. It is more suitable for women who have completed their families because it can affect future fertility and pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option C. Shirodkar surgery: Although similar to sling surgeries, Shirodkar is more commonly associated with cervical cerclage to prevent preterm birth rather than correcting uterine prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a young nulligravida with uterine prolapse and no cystocele or rectocele, abdominal sling surgery (hysteropexy) is the treatment of choice to preserve fertility and provide effective prolapse correction.

questions.text: Which of the following pharyngeal arches do not play a role in the development of the definitive adult tongue? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 2nd pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation: 

 

The 2nd pharyngeal arch does not contribute to the formation of the definitive adult tongue. During tongue development, the 2nd arch mesoderm gets buried below the surface as the 3rd arch mesoderm grows over it to fuse with the mesoderm of the 1st arch. The 2nd arch structures are overgrown and do not form any part of the definitive tongue.

 

Contributions of the other pharyngeal arches:

  • Option A. 1st pharyngeal arch: Forms the anterior two-thirds of the tongue via two lingual swellings and tuberculum impar. This "oral part" of the tongue is innervated by the mandibular branch (V3) for general sensation and chorda tympani (VII) for taste.
  • Option C. 3rd pharyngeal arch: Forms the posterior one-third of the tongue (except the most posterior part). This "pharyngeal part" is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX).
  • Option D. 4th pharyngeal arch: Forms the posterior-most part of the tongue near the vallecula, innervated by the superior laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve (X).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While the 1st, 3rd, and 4th pharyngeal arches contribute to the definitive adult tongue, the 2nd pharyngeal arch mesoderm becomes buried and makes no contribution to the final tongue structure.

questions.text: Identify the operative procedure shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Resection and anastomosis

 

The image shows a suture line between two ends of the bowel, indicating that the ends of the bowel are being joined. This is typically done after a surgical procedure where a segment of the bowel has been removed, necessitating the rejoining of the remaining bowel ends. This procedure is known as resection and anastomosis. The visual cues of the bowel ends being sutured together are indicative of this procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary closure of perforation: This would involve suturing a perforation directly without removing a segment of the bowel, which is not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Ileostomy: This procedure involves creating an opening (stoma) on the surface of the skin, which is not depicted in the provided image. The image shows internal suturing, not an external stoma.

 

Option D. Resection alone: This would mean removing a section of the bowel without rejoining the ends, which is not shown in the image. The image clearly depicts the bowel ends being sutured together, indicating an anastomosis following resection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In surgical procedures involving the bowel, when two bowel ends are being sutured together, the procedure is referred to as resection and anastomosis.

questions.text: Innervation of lateral rectus is by which nerve? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CN VI

 

The lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (abduction), is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This nerve specifically controls the lateral rectus muscle, allowing for the lateral movement of the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CN III (Oculomotor nerve): The oculomotor nerve innervates most of the other extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. It is not responsible for innervating the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option B. CN IV (Trochlear nerve): The trochlear nerve innervates only the superior oblique muscle, which is involved in downward and outward movement of the eye. It does not innervate the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option D. CN VII (Facial nerve): The facial nerve is primarily responsible for the muscles of facial expression. It does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles, including the lateral rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve (CN VI), also known as the abducens nerve.

questions.text: Which one is not helpful in DNA Double stand break repair? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MSH 2

 

MSH 2 is part of the mismatch repair (MMR) system and does not play a direct role in repairing double-strand breaks (DSBs) in DNA. Its main function is to correct base-pair mismatches and insertion-deletion loops during DNA replication and recombination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATM: Ataxia telangiectasia mutated (ATM) protein is crucial for recognizing DNA double-strand breaks and initiating repair via the homologous recombination pathway.

 

Option B. BRCA 1: Breast cancer type 1 susceptibility protein is involved in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks predominantly through the homologous recombination pathway.

 

Option D. Ku 70: Ku 70, along with Ku 80, forms the Ku heterodimer, which binds to DNA double-strand breaks and plays a critical role in the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) repair pathway.

 

Educational objective:

 

MSH 2 is associated with mismatch repair and not directly involved in the repair mechanisms of double-strand breaks, which are crucial processes for maintaining genomic stability and preventing malignant transformations

questions.text: Which of the following structures is intracapsular but extrasynovial? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Long Biceps Tendon

 

The long head of biceps tendon is a classic example of a structure that is intracapsular (inside the joint capsule) but extrasynovial (outside the synovial membrane). As the tendon passes from the supraglenoid tubercle through the shoulder joint to reach the bicipital groove, it pierces the capsule but remains enveloped by a synovial sheath. This unique anatomical arrangement allows the tendon to pass through the joint while maintaining its own synovial environment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoralis Major - This muscle is completely extracapsular and extrasynovial. It inserts onto the lateral lip of the bicipital groove of the humerus and does not enter the joint capsule at any point.

 

Option C. Popliteus Muscle - While the popliteus tendon does have a complex relationship with the knee joint, it is not truly intracapsular and extrasynovial like the long head of biceps. Its tendon passes beneath the lateral collateral ligament outside the joint capsule. Therefore, part of its tendon is intracapsular, while the question muscle itself is largely extracapsular.

 

Option D. Supraspinatus Tendon - This tendon is part of the rotator cuff and lies outside both the joint capsule and synovial membrane, making it extracapsular and extrasynovial. It passes over the shoulder joint capsule but doesn't penetrate it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The long head of biceps tendon has a unique anatomical position as it travels through the shoulder joint capsule (intracapsular) while remaining outside the synovial cavity (extrasynovial), which has important implications for pathological processes affecting this structure.

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sternothyroid

 

  • Sternothyroid and sternohyoid muscles attach to the thyroid cartilage and can help prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling.
  • The apex of thyroid gland is directed laterally to the oblique line of thryroid catilage where it is limited above by the attachment of sternothyroid muscle.
  • The sternohyoid muscle, which arises from the posterior surface of the manubrium and the medial end of the clavicle, also inserts onto the thyroid cartilage and can help anchor the gland in place.
  • Together, the attachment of these muscles to the thyroid cartilage can help prevent the gland from pushing upward and causing compression of adjacent structures in the neck.

 

 

  • The thyroid gland is surrounded by the pretracheal fascia, which is connected to the larynx and enables the thyroid to move during swallowing.
  • The thyrohyoid membrane, a fibrous ligament, attaches to the top of the thyroid cartilage and the hyoid bone, facilitating the upward movement of the larynx during swallowing.
  • The ligament of Berry, also known as the suspensory ligament, extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid gland, preventing it from descending into the mediastinum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pretracheal fascia: The pretracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland, trachea, and associated structures. It anchors the thyroid gland to the trachea, ensuring that the gland moves up and down with swallowing. However, it does not prevent the upward extension of a thyroid swelling specifically through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage.

 

Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane: It is a broad, fibrous sheet that connects the thyroid cartilage (of the larynx) to the hyoid bone. It contains the superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. While it's a strong structure, its primary role is not to prevent the upward extension of thyroid swellings.

 

Option D. Ligament of Berry: It is a band of fibrous tissue that connects the thyroid gland's posterior aspect to the cricoid cartilage and the first two tracheal rings. This ligament is a key anatomical structure that serves to limit the superior (upward) movement of the thyroid gland. When performing thyroid surgeries, the ligament of Berry is a crucial landmark as it is located near the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sternothyroid muscle originates from the posterior surface of the manubrium of the sternum and inserts into the oblique line of the thyroid cartilage. It functions to depress the thyroid cartilage.

questions.text: A patient present with Cotton wool skull. Most likely diagnosis is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paget's disease

 

  • Paget's disease of bone, also known as osteitis deformans, is a chronic disorder that can result in enlarged and misshapen bones. 
  • The condition is named after Sir James Paget, who first described it. 
  • The "cotton wool" appearance of the skull is a radiological hallmark of Paget's disease, resulting from the irregular thickening and softening of the bone. 
  • This appearance is due to a chaotic remodelling process where excessive bone resorption is followed by disorganized bone formation.
  • Thus, the skull X-ray reveal “cotton wool” or osteoporosis circumscripta, thickening of diploic area. Increasing Hat Size!

 

 

Additional Information:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocyotsis: The radiological imaging of the skull in Langerhans cell histiocytosis shows solitary or multiple punched-out lytic lesions without sclerotic rim; double contour or beveled edge appearance due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer; button sequestrum representing residual bone; and geographic skull. 

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: Salt and pepper sign due to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria caused by resorption of trabecular bone in hyperparathyroidism. There is a loss of definition between the inner and outer tables of the skull; a ground-glass appearance; and spotty deossification.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma: Radiographically, multiple myeloma appears as multiple, “punched-out”, sharply demarcated, purely lytic lesions without any surrounding reactive sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "cotton wool" appearance of the skull on radiographs is a classic sign of Paget's disease. 
  • This pattern results from the chaotic bone remodelling process characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysticercosis cellulose

 

The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulose.

 

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

 

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include:

 

  • ﻿﻿Epilepsy
  • ﻿﻿Increased intracranial tension
  • ﻿﻿Hydrocephalus
  • ﻿﻿Psychiatric disturbances
  • ﻿﻿Meningoencephalitis
  • ﻿﻿Transient paresis
  • ﻿﻿Behavioral disorders
  • ﻿﻿Aphasia
  • ﻿﻿Visual disturbances.

 

The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Scolex within a cyst
  • ﻿﻿Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement
  • ﻿﻿Nodular calcifications
  • ﻿﻿Focal enhancing lesions
  • ﻿﻿Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

 

Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

 

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T. saginata: Incorrect. Known as the beef tapeworm, it does not typically lead to cysticercosis as its larvae (Cysticercus bovis) primarily infect cattle.

 

Option C. Cysticercosis bovis: Incorrect. This term is not applicable to human disease and refers to the larval stage of T. saginata found in cattle.

 

Option D. T. asiatica: Incorrect. This is a species of tapeworm similar to T. saginata and is associated with pigs, but like T. saginata, it is not commonly linked to neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis is identified with imaging studies, particularly in patients presenting with new-onset seizures and specific MRI findings of cystic lesions with scolex, is critical for timely diagnosis and appropriate management, including antiparasitic and supportive therapy.

questions.text: In children, which of the following tumors most commonly arises in the epiphysis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Chondroblastoma

 

Chondroblastoma is the most common epiphyseal tumor in children before skeletal maturity. The epiphyseal region is predominantly affected by chondroblastoma followed by giant cell tumor (which typically occurs after skeletal maturity). Chondroblastoma is often referred to as Codman's tumor and characteristically presents with calcification within the epiphysis. It typically appears as a well-defined lytic lesion surrounded by a zone of sclerosis with areas of calcification giving it a mottled appearance radiographically.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) - This is primarily a metaphyseal lesion that occurs in the 2nd decade of life. ABC is multiloculated, eccentric and expansile in nature, commonly affecting the tibia. On MRI, it shows characteristic "fluid-fluid levels" due to its multiple septae.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma - Osteosarcoma characteristically affects the metaphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee (lower femur, upper tibia). It rarely crosses the growth plate into the epiphysis and presents with aggressive features like periosteal reaction and Codman's triangle.

 

Option D. Unicameral Bone Cyst - Also known as Simple Bone Cyst (SBC), this lesion occurs in the metaphysis of long bones, most commonly in the proximal humerus. It typically presents in the 1st decade of life with a central, single cavity containing straw-colored fluid.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chondroblastoma is the most common epiphyseal tumor in children before skeletal maturity, while after skeletal maturity, Giant Cell Tumor becomes the predominant epiphyseal tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following bone tumors most closely resembles osteomyelitis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Ewing's Sarcoma

 

Ewing's sarcoma closely resembles osteomyelitis clinically and radiologically. It typically occurs in the diaphysis of long bones, affects patients in the 1st-2nd decade of life, and often presents with pain, swelling, and fever. The radiological features include onion-peel appearance due to periosteal reaction with layered new bone formation, which can mimic the appearance of osteomyelitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma - While osteosarcoma can also present like osteomyelitis, it is less commonly confused with osteomyelitis than Ewing's sarcoma. Osteosarcoma typically affects the metaphysis (not diaphysis), has a "sun-ray" appearance on X-ray rather than the onion-peel appearance, and shows significant new bone formation with Codman's triangle.

 

 

Option C. Chondrosarcoma - This tumor typically affects patients aged 30-60 years, involves flat bones or upper end of femur, and has characteristic mottled calcification on X-ray. It doesn't present with fever or other inflammatory signs that would mimic osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Osteochondroma - This is a developmental malformation rather than a true tumor, presents as a painless swelling around joints (usually knee), and has a distinctive radiologic appearance showing a bony growth made of mature cortical bone and marrow. It doesn't resemble osteomyelitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ewing's sarcoma most closely mimics osteomyelitis due to its diaphyseal location, presentation with fever, and onion-peel appearance on X-ray—making it an important differential diagnosis in suspected cases of infection.

choices.text: Abduction of the carpo-metacarpal joint of the thumb
Flexion of the MCP joint of the middle finger

questions.text: Injury to the ulnar nerve at the wrist causes paralysis of which function? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Adduction of the thumb

 

In ulnar nerve injury at the wrist (low ulnar nerve palsy), there is paralysis of adduction of the thumb. This occurs because the adductor pollicis muscle is supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve in the hand. The ulnar nerve divides into superficial and deep terminal branches upon entering the palm. The deep branch supplies the adductor pollicis, all interossei, and medial two lumbricals.

 

The function of adductor pollicis can be tested using the "Book Test" or "Froment's sign." When a patient with ulnar nerve palsy attempts to hold a book between the thumb and index finger, they cannot use the adductor pollicis. Instead, they compensate by using the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve), resulting in flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apposition of the thumb - This function is performed by the opponens pollicis muscle, which is supplied by the median nerve, not the ulnar nerve. Apposition is a swinging movement of the thumb across the palm, not simple adduction.

 

Option B. Abduction of the carpo-metacarpal joint of the thumb - This function is performed by the abductor pollicis brevis, which is supplied by the median nerve. It can be tested using the "Pen Test," where the patient touches a pen held above the thumb.

 

Option D. Flexion of the MCP joint of the middle finger - This is primarily performed by the lumbricals. While the ulnar nerve does supply the medial two lumbricals (for the ring and little fingers), the middle finger's lumbrical is supplied by the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ulnar nerve injury at the wrist causes paralysis of adductor pollicis (tested by Froment's sign/Book test), interossei muscles (tested by Egawa's test for dorsal interossei and Card test for palmar interossei), and medial two lumbricals, resulting in a more pronounced claw hand deformity than high ulnar nerve palsy.

choices.text: At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years
At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks

questions.text: What is the f-IPV dose schedule under the National Immunization Schedule of India? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 weeks, 14 weeks, 9 months

 

Under the National Immunization Schedule of India, fractional IPV (f-IPV) is given in three doses:

 

  • First dose at 6 weeks
  • Second dose at 14 weeks (no dose at 10 weeks)
  • Third dose at 9 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fractional IPV (f-IPV) schedule in India's National Immunization Schedule consists of three doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 months.

questions.text: All the following are used for identification of a dead body except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nail

 

Less commonly used due to challenges in extracting sufficient DNA unless recent under-nail samples are available for identifying substances or DNA remnants.

 

Other Options:

 

The various tissues used for identification of a deceased individual vary in their utility and reliability.

 

Option A. Muscle: Can be used for DNA profiling, especially when other tissues are degraded.

 

Option B. Blood: Highly useful for DNA extraction and toxicological analysis to help in identification and determining cause of death.

 

Option D. Hair: Useful if the hair contains follicles; provides DNA which can be crucial for identification purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While nails can sometimes provide useful information, such as traces of substances the individual may have been in contact with, they are less reliable for DNA-based identification compared to other tissues like blood or hair with follicles.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

 

This woman's presentation of recurrent nightmares about a traumatic event (the car accident) that happened two months ago suggests Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD can develop after a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as re-experiencing the trauma (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares), avoidance of reminders of the trauma, negative alterations in mood and cognition, and increased arousal (e.g., irritability, difficulty sleeping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction typically occurs immediately after a traumatic event and lasts for a few days to a few weeks.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder develops in response to a stressor and is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms, rather than the nightmares. It arises within three months of the stressor.

 

Option C. Mania: Mania is characterized by elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep, among other symptoms, and isn't directly related to a traumatic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event, with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response,  severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month. It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is/are true about Crohn’s disease, in contrast to ulcerative colitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More risk of perianal fistulae

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but they have distinct characteristics and should not be considered the same. Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, and is known for causing "skip lesions," meaning areas of diseased tissue interspersed with healthy tissue.

 

  • Perianal fistulae: Crohn’s disease is more associated with perianal complications, including fistulae, abscesses, and fissures, due to the deeper transmural inflammation that characterizes the disease. This is in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosa and submucosa and starts from the rectum, rarely involving perianal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesions are continuous: This statement is incorrect for Crohn’s disease. Continuous lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. In Crohn’s disease, the inflammation is patchy, with skip lesions being typical.

 

Option C. Malignancy is more common: Malignancy is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, particularly colorectal cancer, due to the long-standing inflammation typically confined to the colon. Crohn’s disease has a lower risk of malignancy.

 

Option D. Often presents with hematochezia: Hematochezia, or the passage of fresh blood in the stool, is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Crohn’s disease typically presents with non-bloody diarrhea, although some cases might involve blood, it is not as frequent as in ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crohn’s disease is characterized by a higher risk of perianal fistulae and skip lesions, in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous lesions and a higher risk of colorectal malignancy.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital condition characterized by the abnormal development of the bladder and lower abdominal wall, resulting in the bladder being exposed outside the body. The image shows a typical presentation of bladder exstrophy, with the bladder visible as a red mass on the lower abdomen of the newborn. This condition requires surgical correction to reconstruct the bladder and close the abdominal wall defect.

 

Other Options:

 

Open A. Umbilical hernia: An umbilical hernia is characterized by the protrusion of abdominal contents through an opening in the abdominal muscles near the umbilicus. It typically presents as a soft bulge near the belly button, which is reducible and covered by skin, differing from the exposed bladder seen in bladder exstrophy.

 

Open B. Omphalocele: Omphalocele is a congenital defect where the abdominal contents, such as intestines, liver, and other organs, herniate through the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a protective membrane. It does not involve exposure of the bladder and is distinct from bladder exstrophy.

 

Option D. Gastroschisis: It is an abdominal wall defect where intestines are protruding, but lack a peritoneal covering. The defect is usually to the right side of umbilicus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy presents with the bladder exposed outside the abdominal wall, requiring prompt surgical intervention to correct the defect and reconstruct the urinary tract.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

 The correct matching is:

 

  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a major tumor marker for hepatocellular carcinoma. It's an oncofetal protein that is normally produced during fetal development but can be elevated in certain cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Beta-hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is the primary tumor marker for choriocarcinoma. This marker is normally produced during pregnancy but is pathologically elevated in choriocarcinoma, a malignant trophoblastic tumor.
  • Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine) are elevated in pheochromocytoma, which is a tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes excessive amounts of these hormones.
  • Calcitonin is the characteristic tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma, which arises from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland that produce this hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor Markers

choices.text: Rabies vaccine + Immunoglobulin + Wound management

questions.text: Management of an HIV-positive patient with multiple punctured wound bites caused by a dog is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rabies vaccine + Immunoglobulin + Wound management

 

Multiple punctured wounds classify as Class III bite according to WHO classification. For Class III bites, the standard protocol includes:

 

  • Wound management - washing with running water and soap for 15-20 minutes
  • Local antiseptics if there isn't much bleeding
  • Avoid suturing
  • Administration of both rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin due to severity of exposure The HIV status of the patient doesn't alter this protocol.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Only wound management: Incorrect because Class III bites require comprehensive management including both immunological interventions along with wound care.

 

Option B. Rabies vaccine + Wound management: Incorrect because Class III bites require immunoglobulin in addition to vaccine and wound management.

 

Option D. Immunoglobulin + Wound management: Incorrect because rabies vaccine is essential component of post-exposure prophylaxis and cannot be omitted.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Class III rabies exposure (multiple punctured wounds) requires complete post-exposure prophylaxis including:

 

  • Local wound management
  • Rabies vaccine
  • Rabies immunoglobulin regardless of patient's immune status.

questions.text: Which neonatal condition is the gastric aspirate shake test used to evaluate? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Respiratory distress syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The gastric aspirate shake test is a simple bedside test used to assess pulmonary surfactant in newborns. It evaluates the presence of surfactant in gastric aspirate, which correlates with surfactant levels in the lungs. This test is specifically used to evaluate for Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS), also known as Hyaline Membrane Disease, which is caused by surfactant deficiency in premature infants.

 

In this test, gastric fluid is aspirated from the newborn and mixed with ethanol and saline. The mixture is then shaken and observed for stable foam formation. The presence of stable foam indicates adequate surfactant (negative test), while absence of foam indicates surfactant deficiency (positive test), suggesting RDS.

 

The test is particularly valuable in resource-limited settings where more sophisticated tests like amniotic fluid lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio or lamellar body counts may not be available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal fistula - Incorrect. Diagnosis of TEF usually involves passing a radiopaque nasogastric tube and obtaining radiographs to demonstrate coiling of the tube in the proximal esophageal pouch. The shake test has no role in diagnosing TEF.

 

Option C. Meconium aspiration syndrome - Incorrect. MAS is diagnosed based on history of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, clinical signs of respiratory distress, and characteristic radiographic findings. The shake test is not used in MAS evaluation.

 

Option D. Transient tachypnea of the newborn - Incorrect. TTN is diagnosed based on clinical presentation and radiographic findings showing fluid in the interlobar fissures and perihilar streaking. The shake test doesn't help in TTN diagnosis as surfactant levels are normal in TTN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gastric aspirate shake test is a simple bedside test to evaluate surfactant deficiency in neonates, helping to diagnose Respiratory Distress Syndrome, particularly in settings where sophisticated laboratory tests are unavailable.

questions.text: Which ion's concentration change has the most significant effect on the excitability of cells through RMP? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. K+

 

Explanation:


Potassium (K+) concentration changes have the most significant impact on cellular excitability. The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by K+ gradients across the membrane. In mild to moderate hyperkalemia, the decreased concentration gradient results in less K+ moving outward, leading to depolarization and increased excitability. Conversely, hypokalemia causes hyperpolarization, moving the membrane potential further from threshold and decreasing excitability.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option b. Na+ - While sodium is essential for action potential generation, changes in external Na+ concentration primarily affect the amplitude of action potentials rather than the resting membrane potential. Na+ has little effect on the baseline excitability of cells.
  • Option c. Cl- - Chloride primarily influences inhibitory post-synaptic potentials through influx causing hyperpolarization. Its concentration changes affect modulation of neuronal responses but don't have the most significant effect on baseline cellular excitability.
  • Option d. Ca+2 - Calcium functions as a membrane stabilizing agent. Hypocalcemia increases excitability by decreasing the depolarization threshold needed to initiate action potentials, while hypercalcemia decreases excitability. However, these effects are not as profound as potassium's direct influence on the resting potential.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Potassium concentration directly determines the resting membrane potential, establishing the baseline excitability state of neurons and muscle cells, making K+ the ion whose concentration changes most significantly affect cellular excitability.

questions.text: What is the fluid requirement in a 3-days old baby with a birth weight of 1300 grams? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 120-130 ml/kg/day

 

The fluid requirement for a 3-days old baby weighing less than 1500 grams, such as a baby with a birth weight of 1300 grams, is 120-130 ml/kg/day. This is based on NICU protocols that specify fluid needs according to the day of life and the birth weight of the neonate. At day 3 of life, the recommended fluid intake increases from the previous days to ensure adequate hydration and metabolic support for preterm neonates.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 80-90 ml/kg/day: This fluid requirement is appropriate for the first day of life for preterm neonates with a birth weight of less than 1500 grams, not for the third day.

 

Option B. 100-110 ml/kg/day: This range is suitable for the second day of life for preterm neonates with a birth weight of less than 1500 grams, not for the third day.

 

Option D. 130-150 ml/kg/day: This fluid requirement is higher than the recommended range for a 3-day-old baby weighing 1300 grams. This range is appropriate for the fourth day of life or beyond for preterm neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 3-day-old preterm baby weighing less than 1500 grams, the fluid requirement is 120-130 ml/kg/day. This ensures proper hydration and metabolic support during this critical period.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with palpable purpura, arthritis, and abdominal pain. A diagnosis of IgA vasculitis was made. What is the indication for starting steroids in Henoch Schonlein Purpura?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G.I symptoms

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes. The classic tetrad of symptoms includes palpable purpura (typically on the lower limbs), arthritis, abdominal pain, and hematuria. While the condition is generally self-limiting and resolves within 4-6 weeks, the presence of gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms such as severe abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception warrants the use of steroids. Steroids help reduce inflammation and alleviate the associated GI symptoms, providing significant relief to the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable purpura: Palpable purpura is a common manifestation of HSP, but it does not necessitate steroid treatment. The rash usually resolves on its own without the need for steroids.

 

Option B. Arthritis: While arthritis can cause discomfort and joint pain in HSP, it is typically managed with supportive care and does not require steroids. The arthritis associated with HSP is usually transient and self-limiting.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because GI symptoms are a clear indication for the use of steroids in HSP to reduce severe pain and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), steroids are indicated for the management of gastrointestinal symptoms such as severe abdominal pain or bleeding.
